en: Histoire de l'admirable Don Quixotte de la Manche
SANCHO Panca. Don QUIXOTE de la MANCHA. AMADIS. ROLANDO. DULCINEA.

Don Quixote with the barber basin and Rocinante. Sancho with his donkey. Well-defined iconography.Over the left pedestal, "AMADIS"; over the right one, "ROLANDO". Both as classical statues.Above, a medallion with Dulcinea's portrait.Good engraving.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.
Don Quixote fights with the muleteers / Don Quixote is knighted by the Innkeeper
3.3 Fight with muleteer3.4 DQ knighted at inn by innkeeper

Two different scenes (archaic):The first one, in the background: don Quixote fights with the muleteers during the vigil of his arms.The second one, in the foreground: don Quixote is knighted by the innkeeper while doña Molinera fits his spurs and doña Tolosa his sword.The boy holding a candle that appears in Cervantes' text is missing.Good engraving.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Turned copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.

In the foreground, Juan Haldudo whips Andrés, while in the background don Quixote appears to his assistance.Drawing is ingenuous, disproportionate and without many details, but this composition will be used until the 20th century.Good engraving.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copied after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
Don Quixote is beaten by the silk merchants' groom / Don Quixote is rescued by Pedro Alonso
5.1 End of first sally5.2 DQ rescued by Pedro Alonso

Two different scenes in the same plate (archaic):The first one, in the background: don Quixote is beaten by the Toledo silk merchants' groom.The second scene, in the foreground: don Quixote is taken back home on Pedro Alonso's mule; Rocinante follows them with don Quixote's arms.Acceptable engraving.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copied after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
Don Quixote fighting with the windmills / Don Quixote and the Basque
8.2 Adventure of the windmills (giants)8.3 Episode with friars of St. Benedict8.4 Adventure with the Basque

Three different scenes in the same plate (archaic):In the background, the first one: don Quixote attacks the windmills while Sancho tries to stop him.In the middle ground, the second one: Sancho is beaten by the Benedictine monks' servants.In the foreground, don Quixote fights with the Basque, while a Basque lady observes them from her carriage.The Basque holding a stool is not accurate to Cervantes' text; it should be a cushion.Clumsy drawing, figures without movement and wrong perspective (windmills).Good engraving.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copied after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
14.1 Episode of Grisóstomo and Marcela, continuation14.3 Marcela’s appearance and speech14.4 Burial of Grisóstomo

The background is divided in two parts: down, the dead shepherd, his friend Ambrosio, Vivaldo reading Grisóstomo's song and don Quixote; up, Marcela's appearance and speech.Marcela's figure copies saint Gabriel's traditional image.In the foreground, several shepherds digging Grisóstomo's grave.Burin work is simple.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copied after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
Night adventure at the inn with Maritornes
In the foreground, don Quixote lying on the broken bed.In the background, the fight between Sancho, Maritornes and the muleteer is discovered by the innkeeper, who holds a candle.Good engraving.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copied after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
Sancho Panza's blanketing / Don Quixote fighting with the flock of sheep

Two different scenes in the same plate (archaic):In the foreground, at Juan Palomeque's inn, Sancho's blanketing is observed by don Quixote from behind the inn wall.In the background, don Quixote fighting with a flock of sheep.Simple composition that will be used until the 20th century.Drawing and engraving are poor and simple; barely-printed background.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Turned copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.

In the foreground, don Quixote defeating Alonso López.In the background, the funeral procession companions escaping in great confusion.The engraving, not much detailed, is acceptable, creating a good impression of movement.The night representation is badly resolved; the torch light effects are simple.Acceptable engraving.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copied after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
Don Quixote releases the galley slaves
22.1 Adventure of the galley slaves (galeotes)22.4 Liberation of galeotes

Two different scenes in the same illustration. In the foreground, don Quixote defeats one of the guards, while Sancho releases the slaves. In the background, the consequence: don Quixote and Sancho Panza are stoned by the slaves.Acceptable engraving.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copied after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
Cardenio attacks don Quixote and Sancho Panza
24.1 Story of Cardenio24.3 Cardenio attacks DQ and SP

In the foreground, after defeating don Quixote, Cardenio hits Sancho; the goatherd goes to their assistance.Simple composition.Drawing and engraving are bad and poor in details, but acceptable; figures without naturalism and artificial gestures.Poor printing.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Turned copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
DON QUIXOTTE DE LA MANCHE. Tome Deusieme.
Sancho introducing don Quixote to a pair of gentlemen; one of them kneels down before don Quixote.Drawing and engraving are quite acceptable, but poor.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.
Dispute at the inn about Mambrino's helmet (barber basin) and packsaddle
45.1 Dispute at inn about the Mambrino’s helmet and packsaddle (albarda)

In the center of the composition, don Quixote with Mambrino's helmet (basin barber) shouting to calm down the fight around him (Agramante's Camp); also don Fernando, officers of justice, innkeeper...On the left, Sancho and the barber fighting for the packsaddle.Drawing and engraving are acceptable.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.3 - Wrongly-placed in chapter 30:1.
Resolution of love affairs of Cardenio and Luscinda, and don Fernando and Dorotea
36.2 Resolution of love affairs of Cardenio and Luscinda, Dorotea and Don Fernando

Dorotea recognises don Fernando and Luscinda, who has lost her mask (tafetán), and, knelt down before don Fernando, begs him to let Luscinda go with Cardenio; Sancho, the priest and the barber observe them."Había en este entretanto vuelto Dorotea en sí, y había estado escuchando todas las razones que Luscinda dijo, por las cuales vino en conocimiento de quien ella era: que viendo que Don Fernando aun no la dejaba de sus brazos, ni respondía á sus razones, fué á hincar de rodillas á sus pies" (36:1).Drawing and engraving are acceptable.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
Maritornes and the innkeeper's daughter hang don Quixote from a window by a hand
43.2 Maritornes and innkeeper’s daughter hang DQ from window by a hand43.3 Four travelers arrive at inn

Don Quixote falls from Rocinante and remains hung and tied by his hand to a window when four travelers (servants of don Luis' father) arrive at the inn. Rocinante has moved to smell one of the mares.The innkeeper appears to discover who is shouting.Maritornes is ready to untie don Quixote, but the innkeeper's daughter should not appear in the window too.Drawing and engraving are acceptable.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.

Dorotea (Micomicona) prevents don Quixote from punishing Sancho for having preferred Micomicona's beauty to Dulcinea's. Also the priest, Cardenio and the barber, disguised.Drawing and engraving are acceptable, but poor.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.3 - Wrongly-placed in chapter 45:1.
Don Quixote fights with the goatherd and encounters the penitents
52.1 Fight with the goatherd52.2 Encounter with penitents (disciplinantes)

Two different scenes in the same plate:The first one, in the background: don Quixote fights with the goatherd while the priest, the barber, the officers of the Holy Brotherhood and the canon of Toledo observe them; one of the canon's servants grabs Sancho to prevent him from helping his master.The second scene, in the foreground: Sancho takes care of don Quixote, defeated by one of the penitents, while the priest talk to another priest."El Cura fué conocido de otro Cura, que en la procesión venía, cuyo conocimiento puso en sosiego el concebido temor de los escuadrones" (52:1).Drawing and engraving are acceptable, but poor.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
DON QUIXOTE, CAVALLERO DE LOS LEONES. DULCINEA Encantada. SANCHO PANCA Gubernador. MERLIN. Tome troisieme.

Frontispiece based on don Quixote's Part II iconography (17:2).Don Quixote, as Knight of the Lions (one lion appears beside him), holds a sword and a sun faced shield.Behind him, over a semicircle wall, Dulcinea, as an old peasant woman, and Sancho, as governor.Between them, a medallion with Merlin's portrait.Drawing and engraving are acceptable.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
Don Quixote meets the enchanted Dulcinea
10.2 The three labradoras10.3 SP presents to DQ the enchanted Dulcinea

Well-balanced composition with two different scenes:The first one in the foreground: don Quixote and Sancho kneel down before one peasant girl introduced by Sancho as the enchanted Dulcinea; also two more peasant girls.The second scene in the background: the three peasant girls run away and one of them falls from her donkey, showing her ass (humorous).The same basic composition will be used until the 20th century.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
Don Quixote's encounter with the actors' cart and Sancho's donkey robbery
11.1 Adventure of the cart of actors; “cortes de la muerte”

Thebojigangasteals Sancho's donkey while the squire goes to don Quixote's assistance (falling with Rocinante in the background).In the cart, the actors of Angulo el Malo's company for theCortes de la Muerte(Devil, Cupid, Death, Angel, Emperor, Queen and Soldier); there is one additional player not from Cervantes' text.Drawing and engraving are acceptable, but poor.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
Don Quixote defeats the Knight of the Mirrors
14.2 DQ defeats the knight of the Mirrors

Two different scenes in the same plate:The first one in the background: during the night (not well-represented), Sancho and the Knight of the Mirrors' squire have dinner, while their masters talk.In the foreground, the second scene: in the morning, don Quixote defeats the Knight of the Mirrors (Sansón Carrasco) and his squire (Tomé Cecial) tries to stop him. Sancho observes astonished Sansón Carrasco's face.Tomé Cecial should appear with a fake big nose.Clumsy representation of movement, disproportionate figures and artificial gestures.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
Don Quixote's adventure with a lion

In the foreground, don Quixote gets ready to fight with a lion while the lionkeeper opens the gate of the cage.In the background, Sancho and don Diego de Miranda running away.This composition, with not many changes, will be used until the 20th century.Don Quixote has been drawn crudly.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
22.2 Adventure of the cave of Montesinos

Don Quixote is surprised by a flock of birds when he tries to descend into Montesinos' cave.Sancho Panza and the bachelor's cousin hold the rope to which don Quixote is tied.The lack of expressions makes this illustration quite unconvincing.Drawing and engraving are poor.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
Don Quixote attacks and destroys Maese Pedro's puppets
26.1 Episode of Maese Pedro26.3 DQ attacks and destroys the puppets

Don Quixote attacks Maese Pedro's theater while several astonished witnesses observe him.Maese Pedro appears from under the theater.Theatrical gestures, but without force.This composition, with not many changes, will be used until the 20th century.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.

Two different scenes in the same plate:In the foreground, don Quixote and Sancho, falling from his donkey, are attacked by the members of the braying mayors squadron. Lances are multiplied to suggest agitation and a more numerous group.In the background, don Quixote and Sancho running away.Acceptable drawing and engraving.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
Duke's servants try to wash Sancho's beard

In the foreground, the humorous scene: Sancho bursts into the room followed by Duke's servants, who want to wash his beard with dirty water and towels.In the background, the Duke, the Duchess and don Quixote.Poor engraving.
1 - This illustration did not appear in Paris: Barbin, 1681, so maybe the plate is new.2 - Turned copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
DON QUIXOTTE DE LA MANCHE. Tome Quatrieme.
Don Quixote sat at a table and eating accompanied by Sancho.Behind them, two more figures by the door of an inn (?).Drawing and engraving are poor.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.
35.1 Merlin’s prophecy about Dulcinea and remedy for her enchantment

In the foreground, with their backs turned to the viewer, as shadows, the Duke, the Duchess, don Quixote and Sancho; they observe the entry of Merlin´s cart with Dulcinea (in the background).The scene is resolved with simplicity, without details and little accurate to Cervantes´text (Merlin should appear as Death, not as a magician).Drawing and engraving are poor.
1 - Same plate engraved for Paris: Barbin, 1681.2 - Copy after Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-1673.
